Deftux
Feature Stub

Recent:

Day 90 - Blab's Follow Button

100DaysProject100daysofgoodux

What it is: Blab is a livestreaming conversation platform that is closely integrated with Twitter. The members who are streaming have a small button on them that lets you follow them on Twitter.

Why it’s good: Many new social products, like Meerkat or Product Hunt, are built heavily on top of existing social networks—usually Twitter. With these tight integrations comes a blurring of the lines between the two networks. They each become part of a unified experience that directly feeds into eachother.

Blab could have made a network of their own where you signed up for an account and followed people through their service (like Twitch for instance,) but instead they focused on the goal of their application—a live video multistream. The tight integration supports their goal, and so it lets them play to their strengths. They didn’t reinvent the wheel, but found a way to extend a successful product.

Day 89 - Tinyletter's Search

100DaysProject100daysofgoodux

What it is: When you navigate between different areas of Tinyletter’s web application, the search bar changes to indicate what it would be searching.

Why it’s good: As a user, it can be really difficult to understand the scope of your possibilities. I saw this a lot when working in an agency, in the form of social networking icons. On different sites, these icons could serve a number of different purposes; sharing the page they were on, sharing the site in general, or even navigating to the company’s social properties.

Search can fall into the same trap, sometimes a search is for an entire site and other times it is on for the page that you’re on. In this case, the search being a part of the header makes it fit with Tinyletter’s minimalist design, but it feels like it might be a full site (or in this case, application) search.

With a simple addition of text, it not only reinforces where you are, but it tells you what you can expect to get out of the search. Note that on “Letters” it doesn’t just insert the section name into the search field, but clarifies with “Search Sent Letters.” This minor hint means that I can predict the outcome of my action, which increases my confidence in the interface and in my ability to work with it.

Day 88 - Sloan's Water Saving Handle

100DaysProject100daysofgoodux

What it is: Sloan water saving handles are green, and have a label that indicate which direction you should push the handle to use the water saving function.

Why it’s good: This one feels a little out there, but bear with me. When things look the same, we don’t pay attention to them. They fade into the background and we use them automatically.

Usually, these water saving toilets use a circle cut in two halves. I have no idea what they mean, and I just guess at which of the two buttons to push. I’m wrong a lot.

In this case though, they use the interface I know. The combination of the color shift and the label immediately indicated that this should be used differently. The unifying element is the smart default though, when you pull the handle towards you starts a water saving flush. It’s a safe bet, and definitely the behavior that both the designer (and the store owner) want to encourage.

Day 87 - Codekit's Drag and Drop

100DaysProject100daysofgoodux

What it is: CodeKit is a utility application for preprocessing files and for a host of other supports for modern web development. When adding a project to CodeKit, you can drag and drop the folder onto the window. Dragging a folder onto the window highlights two areas: one to add as a project and the other to add as a framework.

Why it’s good: CodeKit is a Mac App. Macs are particularly suited to dragging and dropping; it’s part of the visual language of the system and is well-established in the user base.

I like this particular solution because of how clearly it shows state and suggests action. First, the top drop area is much larger than it appears. It extends to the title bar and the entire top section of the window. Its increased size and layout emphasize that this is the suggested action—most of the time, you’re adding projects, not frameworks.

CodeKit meets expectations by darkening the section you’re dropping into, but it also takes an extra step in being verbose about it. It highlights the name of the folder that you’re dragging, so in plain language you can see the outcome of your action.

Day 86 - Amazon's Password Field

100DaysProject100daysofgoodux

What it is: When entering a password on Amazon’s mobile app, it is defaulted to show the password in plain text below the obscured password.

Why it’s good: As an industry, we’ve pretty much settled that passwords are pretty terrible for usability, ease of use, and general experience. When we move the password field to a mobile screen, with its constraints on space and lack of tactile feedback, all of these problems are amplified.

These “View Password” toggles feel like a good solution, and they’re popping up with increasing regularity. This particular version of it is my favorite because it shows the plain text password underneath the obscured version. For users who are used to having their password obscured as they type, a plain text field gives them the wrong signal - it doesn’t look correct. Is it secure? Are they even on the password field right now?

This clarifies the relationship between the password and the plain text, and is a safer default, because it has the visual signifier that we’re used to.

Day 85 - iOS's Update Scheduling

100DaysProject100daysofgoodux

What it is: iOS will automatically download updates in the background, and then offer to install them when the device is charging that evening.

Why it’s good: Asking a user to update their device is always a bizarre ritual. We’re asking them to put it down and stop using it for a while, but the only time that they’ll see the message is when they’re already engaged. Seems counterproductive, doesn’t it?

This decision makes so much sense because for the vast majority of the user base, the device will be left unattended in the 5-hour window. This pop-up is effective because of how spare the copy is: direct but still warning of potential pitfalls (i.e. while connected to power)

Pushing programmatic and automated functions into a user’s downtime is a great way to make our products not feel like a chore to manage, or an errand to check off.

Day 84 - Google Drive's Move

100DaysProject100daysofgoodux

What it is: When moving multiple files, Google Docs animates them into a stack, and then shows the stack interacting with its supporting interface pieces.

Why it’s good: In the recent article Your UI isn’t a Disney Movie, Sophie Paxton brings up wonderful points about gratuitous animation in interfaces. She has a great point: animations that aren’t providing meaning are information noise, and end up wasting the user’s time.

In this case though, Google Drive uses small and smart animations to indicate the state of the UI. When working with a web interface, our users don’t usually understand the space of possibilities. Especially in web-based file systems, helping our users understand how they need to interact with the system is vital.The visual stacking happens quickly, and does a wonderful job of showing you where your files are going and what is happening to them.

Day 83 - MileIQ's Categorization

100DaysProject100daysofgoodux

Note: This experience was recommended by my wife, Katelyn. Thanks Katelyn!

What it is: MileIQ is an application to help you keep track of your deductible mileage. It monitors your travel and gives you a breakdown of “Trips” which you categorize into “Business” and “Personal” by swiping. Longer swipes give you the ability to add metadata to the trips as you categorize them.

Why it’s good: This type of interface is now officially known as a “Tinder Swipe”—based off of the eponymous dating app. It’s a great application of the same idea in a different setting.

Reducing the amount of choices to a binary: “Business” or “Personal” is a wonderful statement of the app’s intent. Giving your user a simple, binary choice will always help them move through their data, especially when managing a long list of items. (Notice that she has over 100 drives to categorize)

The implementation of the longer swipe is ingenious. Some applications try to use longer swipes for different pieces of functionality. This is confusing because there isn’t usually a logical linkage between “Short swipe does x, long swipe does y.” There isn’t any map between the gesture and the outcome. This implementation spins it differently, swipe direction accomplishes the action, while longer swipes give you more detail. The mapping is very clear, a larger action in the same domain allows more functionality. Notice that it even maintains the state of the swiped out bar as it fades out the other screen elements.

Day 82 - Clue's Visualizations

100DaysProject100daysofgoodux

Note: This experience was recommended by a reader, who prefers to remain anonymous. Thanks reader!

What it is: Clue is an app for tracking your menstrual cycle. It visualizes the cycle with a circle, and places ranges and data points on it that are positioned relative to different parts of the cycle.

Why it’s good: When I received the glowing email that recommended this product, the main point was the application’s very simple visualization of time. I particularly enjoyed the way that Clue’s creators balanced ranges of time (colored bars around the border) with specific data points (small squares on the inside of the chart).

In the ensuing discussion about the visualization and what made it good, this minorly edited quote summed it up nicely: “Clue allows you an easy way to enter all the data, even providing you with suggestions of things that are related but you may not have thought to track otherwise (i.e. mood). Then, they give all that data back to you in a way that makes you feel more informed about your period… Not only does it allow you to prepare for what’s coming, but also it removes some of the fear caused by experiencing weird symptoms… by showing you what’s ‘normal’ for you.”

The combination of visualization and smart suggestion take something that is inherently hard to predict, and makes it feel more manageable, even when it isn’t.

Day 81 - Eventbrite's Ticket Notification

100DaysProject100daysofgoodux

What it is: When you have an event coming up, Eventbrite sends you a notification. The notification has a QR code in it that serves as your ticket.

Why it’s good: When attending an event, you have a lot going on. Frequently, you are going to a place that you aren’t familiar with, and that brings a lot of complexity. Considering the complexity is usually managed via your phone (with Maps, Calendars, and messaging apps), being required to keep a ticket up on your phone is a liability.

This notification popped up just before the event, and as you can see, they actually put the barcode for my ticket in the notification. This inclusion means that if I was in the midst of navigating or communicating with others, I still have the ticket right there to quickly check in when I find the place.
